elements.title: Information Landscape Before Action Request
elements.problem: The platform asks guests to take action (place a bid) before they have surveyed the full decision landscape. Shomit refuses to bid three separate times despite being told bids are non-binding, because he has not yet seen all options, confirmed his own timeline, or compared prices. The current process interprets early bidding as low-commitment exploration, but the guest interprets any action request as a premature commitment demand. This mismatch produces deferral and dropout: the guest feels pushed before they feel oriented.
elements.solution: Ensure the guest can survey the complete decision landscape before any action is requested. This means: (1) The search phase must let the guest see all matching properties with pricing for their specific schedule before any bid prompt appears. (2) Comparison tools (side-by-side listings, monthly cost equivalents, schedule overlays) must be available and visible before the first call-to-action. (3) The bid prompt should appear only after the guest has interacted with at least two listings, signaling they have begun comparative evaluation. (4) Frame the first action not as 'place a bid' but as 'save this option' or 'mark as interested' to match the guest's actual decision stage. The principle: orientation precedes action, and the platform must confirm orientation before requesting action.

evidence.quote: No, I want to see what the other options are. And also, I'm not sure if when I would start.
evidence.insight: First refusal to bid. Two forms of uncertainty compound: what is available, and when he can begin. The guest needs to resolve both before taking any action.

evidence.quote: I'll still hold off. See the other ones. Right. I mean, it's good to know because, so let's say I get it right. I know I'm not committed to moving forward until I signed the lease.
evidence.insight: Second refusal despite reassurance. Shomit anchors his sense of safety to the final commitment point (lease signing), treating everything before it as exploratory. The platform must respect this exploratory stance rather than pushing toward premature action.

evidence.quote: what people enjoy is not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations. It is not possible to experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines. Only when a doubtful outcome is at stake, and one is able to influence that outcome, can a person really know whether she is in control.
evidence.insight: Csikszentmihalyi's paradox of control: the guest must feel they have enough information to exercise control before they will act. Premature action requests trigger retreat into protective routines ('I'll hold off'). The platform must build the guest's sense of informational mastery before asking them to exercise agency.

evidence.quote: the experience usually occurs when we confront tasks we have a chance of completing. Second, we must be able to concentrate on what we are doing. Third and fourth, the concentration is usually possible because the task undertaken has clear goals and provides immediate feedback.
evidence.insight: Bidding feels incompletable to a guest who has not yet surveyed all options. The task lacks clear goals (which property should I bid on?) and the guest has no feedback mechanism to judge whether a bid is good. The search-before-action pattern provides the goal clarity and feedback that make action feel achievable.

elements.user_goal: Survey all my options and understand the full decision landscape before I take any action, so that when I do act, I act with confidence rather than uncertainty.
elements.company_goal: Increase bid conversion rate by ensuring guests feel informed and oriented before encountering bid prompts, reducing the 'I'll hold off' deferral pattern that leads to permanent dropout.
elements.time_budget: The guest should be able to scan all matching listings in under 60 seconds and compare their top 2-3 options in under 3 minutes before any action prompt appears.
anti_goals: DO NOT prompt the guest to bid before they have seen at least two listings that match their criteria.
DO NOT use the word 'bid' in the first interaction -- it carries auction connotations of obligation that contradict the non-binding nature of the action.
DO NOT interpret the guest's refusal to act immediately as disinterest. It is an information-gathering phase that must be respected and facilitated.
DO NOT hide comparison tools behind the bid flow. Comparison must be freely available without requiring any commitment action first.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of guests who view 2+ listings before their first bid increases to above 70%. Median time from account creation to first bid decreases as guests reach the action stage faster through better orientation tools.

elements.title: Mental Model Translation for Pricing and Schedule
elements.problem: Guests arrive with established mental models from traditional renting. Shomit thinks in monthly rent ('below 2,500 a month is what I would usually spend') but Split Lease prices per night. The agent must manually translate: '$66 per night for 4 nights.' Shomit himself notes this mismatch: 'I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night.' Every time the guest encounters pricing, they must perform a cognitive translation that the platform should do for them. This translation burden accumulates across phases and produces confusion, comparison difficulty, and fatigue.
elements.solution: Automatically translate between the guest's natural mental model (monthly rent, traditional lease terms) and the platform's native model (per-night pricing, partial-week schedules). This means: (1) Every price display should show both the per-night rate and the monthly equivalent for the guest's selected schedule (e.g., '$66/night = $1,056/month for your Mon-Thu schedule'). (2) Provide an explicit comparison frame: 'vs. a full-time lease at $2,500/month, you save $1,444/month.' (3) The schedule selector should show calendar views alongside night counts, so guests can see their actual days rather than abstract numbers. (4) When schedule changes affect price, show the monthly impact immediately, not just the per-night change. The principle: translate into the user's existing mental model rather than forcing them to learn a new one.

evidence.quote: I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night... I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time. I think go, like, what kind of place would I rent for myself? Right. Probably below 2,500 a month is what I would usually spend.
evidence.insight: Shomit's pricing mental model is monthly rent from traditional NYC leasing. He explicitly describes having to translate between his natural frame (monthly) and the platform's frame (per night). This cognitive overhead repeats at every pricing touchpoint.

evidence.quote: four nights will be get $66 per night And that is including all taxes fees.
evidence.insight: The agent provides the per-night rate but not the monthly equivalent. Shomit must mentally compute $66 x 4 nights x ~4 weeks = ~$1,056/month. The platform should do this math automatically and surface the comparison.

evidence.quote: Activities that provide enjoyment are often those that have been designed for this very purpose... it would be a mistake to assume that only art and leisure can provide optimal experiences... one purpose of this book is to explore ways in which even routine details can be transformed into personally meaningful games that provide optimal experiences.
evidence.insight: Csikszentmihalyi argues that routine interactions can become engaging when properly designed. The pricing translation is currently a cognitive burden, but if designed as an interactive, immediate-feedback tool ('slide to add a night, see your monthly cost update in real time'), it becomes an engaging exploration rather than arithmetic homework.

evidence.quote: The reason it is possible to achieve such complete involvement in a flow experience is that goals are usually clear, and feedback immediate.
evidence.insight: Pricing evaluation requires immediate feedback: each schedule change should instantly show the monthly cost impact. Without this, the guest is operating without feedback and cannot evaluate whether an option fits their budget.

elements.user_goal: Instantly understand what any listing will cost me per month in terms I already know, without having to do mental math or learn a new pricing vocabulary.
elements.company_goal: Reduce pricing confusion that leads to sticker shock, budget mismatches, and abandoned searches. Enable guests to self-qualify against their budget without agent intervention.
elements.time_budget: The guest should understand the monthly cost of any listing for their specific schedule within 2 seconds of viewing it. No mental calculation should be required.
anti_goals: DO NOT show only per-night pricing without monthly context. The guest's budget is monthly, so the price must be presented monthly.
DO NOT force the guest to learn Split Lease's pricing logic before they can evaluate affordability. The translation layer should be invisible.
DO NOT present pricing as a single number without comparison anchors. The guest needs to see 'what this costs vs. what I would normally pay.'
DO NOT require the guest to navigate to a separate calculator or tool. The translation must be inline, immediate, and automatic.
elements.success_metric: Reduction in agent-handled pricing questions by 40%. Increase in the percentage of guests who enter a bid with a monthly cost within their stated budget range.

elements.title: Co-Tenancy Uncertainty Resolution Across Phases
elements.problem: The co-tenancy model introduces a layer of social uncertainty that persists across the entire guest journey. Shomit's immediate reaction to learning about shared space is hedged acceptance: 'I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.' The triple 'I guess' signals unresolved evaluation, not genuine acceptance. The current process addresses co-tenancy only verbally (on a phone call) and once (at the Zoom matching meeting). But the uncertainty re-emerges at every phase: during listing evaluation (what will the shared space feel like?), at move-in (evidence of the other person's presence), and during active lease (ongoing co-tenant dynamics). The platform treats co-tenancy as a one-time explanation rather than a persistent concern requiring structured resolution.
elements.solution: Design co-tenancy information and reassurance as a persistent thread woven through every relevant phase, not a one-time disclosure. This means: (1) During discovery, provide a clear visual or narrative explanation of the 'ghost roommate' concept with specific examples of how it works in practice. (2) On listing pages, include a dedicated section addressing the shared-space arrangement: what is shared, what is private, how transitions work, what cleanliness standards are maintained. (3) Before the Zoom co-tenant meeting, provide the guest with a preparation guide: what to expect, what to ask, what criteria to evaluate, and explicit reassurance that they can decline. (4) At move-in, include a co-tenancy FAQ in the arrival materials addressing the most common concerns (other person's belongings, cleaning, key handoff). (5) During active lease, provide a structured channel for co-tenant communication or concern escalation. The principle: resolve social uncertainty proactively at every phase where it can resurface, rather than relying on a single explanation.

evidence.quote: Where does that other person go? ... I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.
evidence.insight: Triple hedging reveals unresolved evaluation. Shomit accepts the concept verbally but has not genuinely resolved his uncertainty. His 'it doesn't really matter to me' is self-reassurance, not conviction. This uncertainty will resurface at every subsequent phase.

evidence.quote: you will meet on zoom that person, and you will talk to the tourist. So you will be able to say, I am comfortable or not comfortable with the other person who is going to use it to a party when you're not there.
evidence.insight: The Zoom meeting is the only structured co-tenancy resolution point. But it occurs weeks into the process and depends on matching. Before that meeting, the guest carries unresolved social uncertainty through search, evaluation, and proposal phases.

evidence.quote: Another universally enjoyable activity is being with other people. Socializing might at first sight appear to be an exception to the statement that one needs to use skills to enjoy an activity, for it does not seem that gossiping or joking around with another person requires particular abilities. But of course, it does; as so many shy people know, if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts, and avoid company whenever possible.
evidence.insight: Csikszentmihalyi identifies social interaction as a skilled activity. The co-tenant Zoom meeting is a high-stakes social interaction that the guest may not feel prepared for. Without preparation and structure, this interaction becomes a source of anxiety rather than engagement.

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
evidence.insight: The co-tenancy arrangement is fundamentally 'unseen' by the guest until move-in. Like the blind women, guests evaluating a shared-living arrangement they have never experienced need richer, more explicit feedback about what the arrangement will actually be like. The absence of direct experience must be compensated with structured information.

elements.user_goal: Understand exactly what sharing a space with a stranger means for my daily experience, with enough clarity at every phase that I never feel surprised or uncomfortable about the arrangement.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate co-tenancy uncertainty as a dropout driver by converting it from a persistent background concern into a resolved, even positive, feature of the value proposition.
elements.time_budget: Co-tenancy information on a listing page should take under 15 seconds to scan. The Zoom meeting preparation guide should take under 2 minutes to read. Move-in co-tenancy FAQ should take under 1 minute.
anti_goals: DO NOT treat co-tenancy as a one-time explanation that is 'handled' after the initial phone call or discovery page.
DO NOT leave the Zoom co-tenant meeting unstructured. Provide both parties with conversation guides and evaluation criteria.
DO NOT minimize or dismiss the guest's co-tenancy concerns. Acknowledge that sharing space with a stranger is unusual and address it directly.
DO NOT wait until the guest asks about co-tenancy to provide information. Surface it proactively at every phase where it is relevant.
elements.success_metric: Reduction in co-tenancy-related questions to agents by 50%. Increase in Zoom meeting completion rate (guests who schedule and attend the co-tenant meeting). Post-move-in satisfaction scores for the co-tenancy arrangement above 4/5.

elements.title: Immediate Feedback at Every Process Gap
elements.problem: The guest journey contains multiple gaps where the guest takes an action and then receives no feedback for an extended period. After the phone call, the guest waits for an email with an account link. After placing a bid, the guest waits for a match. After the match, the guest waits for a Zoom meeting. After the Zoom meeting, the guest waits for a lease. The agent describes a two-to-three-week process timeline. Shomit's metaphor -- 'so like courtship' -- reveals how the guest experiences this: as a prolonged, uncertain process with no guaranteed outcome. Each gap is a dropout opportunity because the guest's attention returns to competing priorities and the platform provides no feedback to sustain engagement.
elements.solution: Close every process gap with immediate, structured feedback that tells the guest what happened, what is happening now, and what happens next. This means: (1) After account creation, immediately show the guest their pre-populated search results based on the call parameters (location, budget, schedule), not an empty dashboard. (2) After a bid is placed, provide instant confirmation with a progress tracker: 'Bid received > Matching in progress > Meeting scheduled > Lease prepared.' (3) At every waiting period, provide either a time estimate ('typical matching takes 5-7 days') or a status update mechanism (email/SMS when status changes). (4) Between major milestones, send brief engagement touchpoints: 'New listing matching your criteria,' 'Your bid is in the top 3 for this property,' or 'Your co-tenant match is confirmed -- here is what to expect next.' The principle: no moment in the journey should leave the guest wondering 'what is happening with my application.'

evidence.quote: It's usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process and get Lisa [lease].
evidence.insight: A two-to-three-week process with no described intermediate feedback creates multiple dropout windows. Each day without feedback reduces the guest's engagement and increases the probability they solve their housing need elsewhere.

evidence.quote: So like courtship.
evidence.insight: Shomit's courtship metaphor is revealing: courtship requires sustained mutual interest with no guaranteed outcome. If the platform does not demonstrate sustained interest (through feedback and updates), the guest will assume the 'courtship' has ended.

evidence.quote: The reason it is possible to achieve such complete involvement in a flow experience is that goals are usually clear, and feedback immediate.
evidence.insight: Csikszentmihalyi identifies immediate feedback as one of the core conditions for engagement. The guest journey currently violates this condition at every major transition, replacing immediate feedback with silence and waiting.

evidence.quote: Certain activities require a very long time to accomplish, yet the components of goals and feedback are still extremely important to them. One example was given by a sixty-two-year-old woman living in the Italian Alps, who said her most enjoyable experiences were taking care of the cows and tending the orchard: 'I find special satisfaction in caring for the plants: I like to see them grow day by day. It is very beautiful.'
evidence.insight: Even long processes can sustain engagement if they provide incremental feedback. The guest's two-to-three-week journey needs visible 'growth' indicators: a progress tracker, status updates, or new information that shows the process is advancing, analogous to watching plants grow day by day.

elements.user_goal: Always know where I stand in the process, what is happening right now, and what will happen next, so I never feel like my application has disappeared into a void.
elements.company_goal: Reduce dropout during the multi-week process by maintaining guest engagement through structured feedback loops that sustain attention between major milestones.
elements.time_budget: After any guest action (bid, account creation, meeting completion), feedback should arrive within 5 seconds in-platform or within 1 hour via email/SMS. Status updates during waiting periods should arrive at least every 48 hours.
anti_goals: DO NOT allow any period longer than 48 hours to pass without the guest receiving some form of status communication.
DO NOT provide only the final outcome (lease ready or not) without intermediate progress signals.
DO NOT rely on the guest to check the platform for updates. Push feedback to them through the channel they already use (email, SMS).
DO NOT describe the timeline in vague terms ('two to three weeks'). Provide specific milestones with estimated dates.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of guests who remain active (log in or respond to communication) through the full matching period increases to above 60%. Median time from bid to lease signing decreases as feedback loops accelerate guest responsiveness.

elements.title: Physical Verification Path Before Commitment
elements.problem: Shomit asks 'is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?' -- revealing that digital listing information alone is insufficient for a guest with extensive rental experience. He is accustomed to physically visiting apartments before committing. The platform's current process does not clearly offer or structure in-person viewing. This leaves a gap between the digital representation and the guest's confidence in the physical reality. For guests evaluating a co-tenancy arrangement -- where the physical condition of shared space is even more critical than in a standard rental -- the inability to verify the space before commitment creates a trust deficit that no amount of listing photography can fully resolve.
elements.solution: Provide a clear, structured path for physical verification that fits naturally into the guest journey without slowing the process. This means: (1) On every listing page, include an explicit 'Visit this property' option with clear instructions on how to schedule a viewing. (2) If in-person viewing is not always possible, compensate with rich media: video walkthroughs, 360-degree photos, detailed room measurements, and photos of the shared spaces in their actual lived-in condition (not just staged photos). (3) After the Zoom co-tenant meeting, offer a guided property visit as the natural next step before lease signing. (4) At move-in, provide a brief digital walkthrough or checklist that confirms the property matches the listing, closing the loop between digital promise and physical reality. The principle: the guest needs sensory confirmation that the space is real and adequate before they will commit, and the platform must provide a path to that confirmation.

evidence.quote: is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?
evidence.insight: The phrasing 'is that allowed?' reveals Shomit is uncertain whether the platform supports physical viewing. This uncertainty itself is a friction point: even if viewing is available, the guest does not know it. The option must be explicit and prominent.

evidence.quote: I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time. I think go, like, what kind of place would I rent for myself?
evidence.insight: Shomit's extensive NYC rental experience has established a strong expectation that you see a place before you commit. The platform must either meet this expectation or provide a compelling alternative that achieves the same trust outcome.

evidence.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
evidence.insight: Guests evaluating listings remotely are in an analogous situation to the blind women: they cannot see the actual space. They need compensatory feedback -- richer media, more explicit detail, verification mechanisms -- to close the gap between digital representation and physical reality.

evidence.quote: the clearly structured demands of the activity impose order, and exclude the interference of disorder in consciousness.
evidence.insight: A structured verification path (schedule visit > confirm property > sign lease) imposes clear order on the evaluation process. Without this structure, the guest's consciousness is disordered by uncertainty about whether the space matches the listing.

elements.user_goal: Confirm with my own senses that the property I am committing to is real, clean, and matches what was represented online, before I sign anything.
elements.company_goal: Increase conversion from listing evaluation to lease signing by removing the trust gap between digital representation and physical reality. Reduce post-move-in complaints and early terminations caused by expectation mismatches.
elements.time_budget: The option to schedule a property visit should be visible within 5 seconds of viewing a listing. If in-person viewing is not available, the compensatory media (video, 360 photos) should take under 2 minutes to review.
anti_goals: DO NOT make the guest ask whether viewing is possible. Surface the option proactively on every listing page.
DO NOT rely solely on staged professional photography. Show the space in its actual lived-in condition to set accurate expectations for a co-tenancy arrangement.
DO NOT treat physical verification as optional for high-value listings. For listings above a certain price threshold, actively encourage in-person visits.
DO NOT let the physical visit be an unstructured experience. Provide a checklist of what to look for during the visit.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of guests who request or complete a property viewing before signing a lease. Post-move-in satisfaction scores for 'property matched expectations' above 4.2/5.

elements.title: Challenge-Skill Balance in the Process Complexity
elements.problem: The Split Lease model introduces a level of process complexity (co-tenancy, dynamic pricing, non-binding bids, Zoom matching, multi-week timeline) that may exceed the guest's readiness to engage. Shomit has extensive NYC rental experience, which means he has high general housing skills but zero Split Lease-specific skills. The current process dumps the full complexity at once during the phone call: co-tenancy explanation, pricing model, bid system, matching process, Zoom meeting, lease timeline. This violates Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance: when challenges exceed a person's perceived capacity to act, the result is anxiety, not engagement. Shomit's response pattern -- accepting information but refusing to act -- is a classic anxiety-zone behavior.
elements.solution: Sequence the introduction of process complexity to match the guest's growing familiarity. This means: (1) During discovery, explain only the value proposition ('a furnished apartment for the nights you need, at a fraction of full-time rent') and one next step ('browse available properties'). Do not explain bids, matching, Zoom meetings, or co-tenancy in the first interaction. (2) During search, introduce dynamic pricing as the guest interacts with the schedule selector -- let them discover it through immediate feedback rather than verbal explanation. (3) Introduce the bid concept only after the guest has selected a preferred listing, when the action has a clear target. (4) Explain co-tenant matching and the Zoom meeting only after a bid is placed, when the guest is already invested and the next step is concrete. The principle: introduce each new process element only when the guest has the context and motivation to absorb it, never earlier.

evidence.quote: let me just a quick explain you how's this work to make sure we all the same page... the two people who acting sort of like ghost roommates... the same space is used by different people... the cost for you is significantly less.
evidence.insight: The agent attempts to explain the entire model in one block: co-tenancy, shared space, cost savings, schedule splitting, landlord relationship. This is a large amount of novel information for a guest who is still in the discovery phase. The guest must absorb all of it before being asked to act.

evidence.quote: I guess like a few, this is good, right? Except for like one or two things.
evidence.insight: Shomit signals partial acceptance ('this is good') with reservations ('except for like one or two things'). He has absorbed the value proposition but has unresolved concerns. Dumping more complexity at this point (bid process, matching, timeline) before resolving his existing questions produces the deferral pattern seen throughout the rest of the call.

evidence.quote: Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.
evidence.insight: Csikszentmihalyi's foundational principle: too much challenge relative to skill produces anxiety; too little produces boredom. The guest journey must calibrate the challenge level (process complexity) to the guest's current skill level (familiarity with Split Lease).

evidence.quote: Any activity contains a bundle of opportunities for action, or 'challenges,' that require appropriate skills to realize. For those who don't have the right skills, the activity is not challenging; it is simply meaningless.
evidence.insight: For a guest unfamiliar with the Split Lease model, being asked to 'enter a bid' before understanding what a bid means in this context is not challenging -- it is meaningless. The action must become meaningful through gradual skill-building before the guest encounters it.

elements.user_goal: Learn how Split Lease works naturally as I go through the process, without being overwhelmed by the full complexity before I am ready to handle it.
elements.company_goal: Reduce early-stage dropout caused by process complexity overload by introducing concepts sequentially, matching the guest's growing understanding and reducing the anxiety that leads to 'I'll hold off' behavior.
elements.time_budget: Each new concept should be introduced in under 30 seconds of reading or interaction. No single phase should introduce more than one novel process concept (co-tenancy, bidding, matching, Zoom meeting).
anti_goals: DO NOT explain the full process (bid > match > Zoom > lease) in the first interaction. Reveal each step only when the guest needs it.
DO NOT assume that explaining a concept verbally means the guest has absorbed it. Understanding comes through interaction, not explanation.
DO NOT front-load complexity to 'set expectations.' The guest's expectations are set by their experience, not by an information dump.
DO NOT treat the phone call as the sole onboarding mechanism. The platform itself must provide progressive disclosure of process complexity.
elements.success_metric: Reduction in the number of concepts explained per phone call (from 5+ to 2-3). Increase in the percentage of guests who complete their first platform action (browse listings) within 24 hours of account creation.
